content: imagine this crazy thing comes down a dungeon hallway towards a group of
adventurers an iron gate slams down behind them and there's only one way out
past this ridiculous killing machine
hey guys welcome back to black magic crafts this week is another no plan
household junk kind of build and I went into it with absolutely no idea as to
what I was going to make and somehow I ended up making this crazy thing I'm not
sure what that says about my psyche and state of mind but it sure is friggin
cool-looking I started by looking through some boxes of random stuff that
I had saved surprisingly I didn't choose a skull to work with I thought I'd
finally make something out of the to juice lids that I'd been saving for
quite some time the shapes of these would have made great bases for statues
or something but I wanted to think a little bit outside the box right away I
thought they could make some sort of cool dungeon trap a rolling crushing bit
of steel to fill a narrow hallway and I had to join them and to end on the thin
rim of the lids and after my cat food can build last week I knew I couldn't
simply just glue them together so I broke out some XPS foam my procs on and
a circle cutting jig and made a foam plug to join the two lids I actually
left them spaced apart as this would make the thing wide enough to fill my
most used 3x3 tiles something like this is way more
intimidating if there's no room in the hallway for a player to move past it the
lids had some fins inside that easily cut into the foam plug and with that and
a bit of hot glue it was really easy to assemble this I didn't want any exposed
foam on the project so I cut a strip of construction paper to wrap around and
cover the XPS and obviously obviously this thing needed a whole bunch of
spikes otherwise what's the point I also needed to cover the branding
imprint on the lids some circles cut out of construction paper would be ideal I
didn't trust myself to cut perfect circles with scissors so I decided to
give the foam core circle cutter thing I have another try not sure if it would
work on paper spoiler alert it didn't it is not meant for this so I cut out a
disc of regular foam core instead but I really didn't want to go with something
not thick and I really didn't want it to be foam screw it just trace the circle
cut it with scissors I really wanted to make some mechanical insect type legs
and I figured they would look fast if they were made out of individual pieces
so I made templates out of paper that I then transferred to medium weight
chipboard word of advice when cutting chipboard like this take your time make
several light passes this will give you the cleanest possible cut and avoid
ripping and swelling the edges of the cuts I'd also like to advise
transferring the paper outline only once then use your first chipboard piece as
the template moving forward it's a bit easier to work with
I decided on four legs this should mean four of each piece but I thought it
would look cool if the center piece was actually layered so I had to cut double
the amount of those ones figuring out positioning and assembly was a bit
tricky but with a bit of patience and PVA glue I managed to get through it
relatively painlessly
I had reinforced all of the joints with PVA but I didn't trust it for coding the
rest of the chipboard PVA simply shrinks too much and would cause too much
warping so I opted of course for Mod Podge as it shrinks and warps paper far
less sealing this paper material not only makes it harder and more durable
but it's a crucial step for protecting it during the painting process later I
really didn't want these legs to swell and warp now to actually attach the legs
at first I thought the rolling spike thing would be up off the ground and it
would just kind of stand and walk on its legs not a chance
way too wobbly no hope in hell of that working so Plan B rip off two of the
legs and move them to the front letting the Beast rest on the main body
in order to do this I had to cut down some of the spikes on the underside so
it sat flat and I decided to position the second set of legs in a pretty
menacing way that I thought looked really damn cool I added some small
gears on the joints to give this thing some character and imply mechanics these
are just some little decorative jewelry bits that I got at Michaels and hadn't
really gotten around to using before the back of the machine was looking rather
naked and boring so I started to visualize how this machine worked and
thought well it would be neat if it had a net or a bucket on the back to throw
the corpse as it created into super gnarly right for the cage scoop bucket
thing I just used a plastic hair curler it was the perfect length and it looked
the part to make the long joint really strong I used the old baking soda and
superglue trick because there was a gap between the two pieces I used some
masking tape to create a dam this created a really strong joint that had
the texture of an ugly weld or rust perfect for this application a little
bit of plastic needlepoint mashin this corpse catcher was complete
now you might be thinking but Jeremy the
position of the legs here is totally different than on the finished product
and you are correct I started looking at it again and going how the hell does
this thing actually work two sets of legs on the front that are in line they
would just hit each other they'd have nowhere to go
how would it spin it really didn't make any sense whatsoever so I cut off two of
the legs don't be afraid to pivot midway through a project even for a second time
cut off stuff if you have to it's fine I went back to my original positioning but
this time around the main body was resting firmly on the ground making the
whole thing far more stable now it could walk forward and backwards you know the
idea is that it crawls down the hall the center spike thing spins catches a
corpse sends it over crushes it to the ceiling dumps it in the bucket and once
the whole Hall is cleared of peski adventurers the back legs could crawl it
back and maybe there's a pit that opens up and the bucket thing dumps the bodies
into the pit but you know kind of makes sense now a little bit at this point it
was time to get into painting and I first primed it in matte black primer
after it had dried I thought it needed more texture for rust there's no way
this machine resting in a damp dungeon for who knows how long wouldn't be
covered in heavy rust so I used some Vallejo texture paste to create the
rusty patches you could absolutely get a similar effect with very fine powder
like grout or baking soda mixed with a bit of glue or acrylic caulking then I
painted the whole thing with a dark black metallic followed by a gunmetal
grey then I mixed black and brown washes to really grime this thing up these
Vallejo washes that come in the big tubs are far stickier than my homemade black
washes or their smaller bottle counterparts this is often a problem on
build but in this case it was ideal as actually wanted the wash to not run off
everything intact more as a filter and a layer of Filth
now back to the airbrush I used a variety of brown sepia black and rusty
inks and washes to create all the rust effects now hold up a second Jeremy I
need to speak to you and I want you to remember this Jeremy look at how this
thing looks right now it looks pretty good the color of the metal is nice and
grimy it looks aged and old but you decided it needed some orange rust like
you often do and like you often do you add it a little and then you added more
by the end of it it turned out orange and bronzy looking and arguably worse
than it did before you added this step maybe next time take a long look at
something before you move on because maybe it already looks awesome and you
should leave it the way it is oh well it is what it is time to add some wet
engine oil washes to the moving parts the last thing this mechanical death
machine needs is a whole lot of blood effects
I wanted a combination of old dried blood streaks as well as fresh blood
splatter and for the old blood I use straight acrylic ink
I used a mixture of both very bright red and a burnt umber I wanted this blood to
be dried which should be rather dark brown I had a feeling the pure red over
the rust color would actually dry dark enough but I wasn't sure so I played it
safe and also use some of that burnt umber
for the fresh blood I mix the bright red ink with Vallejo water texture and just
kind of went to town splattering it and splotching it all over

hold because I really want to drop this thing into a dungeon just to see my

mine I'm not gonna waste time planning out a solution don't come up with
something on their own or they won't and it will end up in a party white but

enjoyable entertaining inspiring if you did hit the like button and let me know

to allowing me the time and giving me the resources to actually produce these

I'd love to have you as the newest member that's it for this week guys
Cheers happy crafting
